options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture, live section
NA
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, and virtual discussion section.
none
Lectures were recorded as well
Weekly virtual sections where we discussed material and problem-solving.
Live lectures were recorded and posted for later viewing, and there was a discussion section once a week.
There were also virtual discussion sections.
Combination of live virtual lectures and live virtual discussions.
virtual section once a week as well
Lecture was recorded but synchronous
I attended live virtual lecture along with live virtual discussion sections.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Critical thinking on philosophical concepts
interesting discussions of infinity and related concepts, touching on different math (proof techniques, set theory, analysis, topology, probability)
Discussion of paradoxes of the infinite, changed my way of thinking about the world, the nature of reality etc
I learned about various paradoxes involving infinity, some theories on counting and natural numbers, theories on space

I learned how to think philosophically about assumptions in sciences that I have always assumed to be correct. It was incredibly interesting and satisfying to be able to think about the topic of infinity in a philosophical context and to be able to rigorize thoughts processes through experiments. I learned about the history of understanding differences in infinity, and how gradually certain assumptions became popularized in fields of science.
I developed my thinking skills -- ie. in pinpointing flawed arguments. I learnt about interesting paradoxes and the concept of infinity.
Learned to have intelligible conversation on the topic of infinity and how to approach a variety of arguments.
Understanding the concept of infinity and its application to different disciplines

This course really helped me develop my analytical reasoning. It was a fascinating introduction to the topic of infinity, and helped me expand my critical thinking and analytic capacities, along with being very fun!
Concept of infinity and potential infinity, zeno paradoxes, probability stuff etc

I learned much more about philosophical argumentation through reading, discussing, and especially writing. I also learned a lot about the history and underlying theory behind everyday concepts (e.g. counting, measuring). I got my first introduction to proofs in this class, which will be helpful for other math classes. And, of course, I gained a deeper understanding of the concept of infinitywhat is actually meant by it, the differing types/sizes of infinity, the mathematical rules applicable to infinities, the paradoxes surrounding it, and so on.
This class taught me a lot of the historical and philosophical underpinnings of mathematical ideas that I have learned in other math classes.
I developed a basic understanding of the philosophical concept of infinity, various related paradoxes and elementary set theory.
Considered the various paradoxes related to infinity, gained some understanding of basic real analysis.

This course was my first dive into Philosophy, and I learned much about the field through the medium of mathematics. This class was a very effective blend of the two fields, and really challenged my ability to think logically and write in a clear and concise manner about paradoxes and other examples of infinity.

This course allowed me the opportunity to practice creative thinking, pursuing avenues of thought outside of our normal accepted ways of thinking. I was taught to question how exactly we know things and how much we can stretch our knowledge in order to understand the concept of infinity. I learned how to craft arguments and explanations in a succinct and organized way. This course also provided a review/investigation into mathematical topics that was quite enjoyable and applicable.  Discussion section allowed me to engage in fully interactive conversation and practice crafting positions/opinions on the spot.
Critical thinking of large mathematical issues and ability to argue my point using mathematical facts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Loved this course

A surprising amount of math was covered, though at a very survey-type level of depth. The ideas of the course are fairly interesting and the discussion in section were pretty worthwhile , though in the end, did not really learn much concrete about infinity (esp if you have already seen most of the math.

Really fascinating subject material, sadly there's no answers to any of the questions we discuss which feels unsatisfying, if immensely interesting. For a class with no prerequisites, the beginning of the class almost scared me off with the math. The second half of the course was more philosophical which I enjoyed more.
I liked how it assumed very little background knowledge of philosophy. It does assume familiarity with a lot of mathematical concepts, which makes it difficult to understand topics.

S - Prof Maxwell is very knowledgeable and passionate about the material, which makes for engaging lectures. The content is immediately interesting and thought-provoking, which makes analysis of the arguments all the more fruitful.
W - The lecture format got a bit repetitive sometimes
The slides were often difficult to follow, in lecture and afterwards. Professor made up for it with his insight.
Good lectures and discussion sections, with assignments that felt doable and applicable to our lectures. Overall very good
This course was definitely harder than I expected. My TF was very helpful in section and otherwise, but the lecture slides were generally confusing and the lectures were not well-explained.

This was one of the most enjoyable courses I have taken at Yale! The questions we dealt with were fascinating, and the problems we had to solve were more like games than homework - it was really interesting to think them through alone and in groups. Also, Professor Maxwell and our TA's were clearly very enthusiastic and engaged with the material, and that made it all the more exciting to think about the material as a student.
I thought the material was quite good. I thought the pset questions were ok, but the midterm was a bit weird. It was more of a time crunch than anything and I found the grading to be rather weird.

The professor and teaching fellows were greatgood explanations of complex concepts, very accommodating to student needs, and great about stopping for questions and discussion after a good amount of content had been covered. The midterm covered and asked a lot in only an hour, but the questions were fair and the curve was generous. The only weakness for this course would be the time it took to get back our graded problem sets. It wasn't too much of a problem until the end of the semester when students were left unsure where their grades stood for the class.

As a Humanities major, I felt a little lost in this class. Of course thats not the fault of the class, but I definitely think it wouldve been helpful to either include more detailed, extensive explanations of various concepts for those who arent already familiar, or change the description of the class to indicate to prospective students that a little bit more familiarity with mathematical concepts is expected.

There should have been some sort of mathematical prerequisite to this course, because a lot of time was spent reviewing the basic math. A lot of questions that have been resolved were posed but not answered, which was somewhat disappointing. More discussion about the place of infinity in the physical rather than metaphysical world(s) would also have been nice.

The course was very thorough and did a really good job of explaining very complex themes and problems. It was engaging and the readings helped to understand the lectures better. However, I found it difficult to learn from my mistakes on problem sets/tests/papers because the feedback was sparse or unclear, requiring me to meet with my TA.

I appreciated how the professor would star or place a question mark on the presentation slides with information that we were expected to know. This division between supplemental information and crucial information allowed me to more effective study for exams and prepare for discussion section. The discussion sections were very helpful in enforcing my understanding of the material. Allowing students in the section to lead the conversation and guide it in a direction we wanted to investigate increased engagement.
The course started off in quite a dull way with huge amounts of mathematical proof but it proved useful later on in the course. I do prefer the philosophy side of the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: NA
Sections and lectures worked great, no problems here
I thought the class adapted well to the situation, and thoroughly enjoyed both lectures and discussion sections.
The course went as well as possible with virtual classes
The in-class exam was difficult (lots of material in a short amount of time) but aside from that everything was well suited for virtual learning

I liked the virtual live lecture format - it was a lecture, which was needed in order to give us a grasp of the material, but was live, which helped it feel more engaging and allowed us to ask questions at the end. The sections were also very helpful, and it was refreshing to get to discuss the material in a smaller group, even over Zoom.

I think the professor and TFs did a good job at structuring this class for remote learning. Having live lectures + uploading the recorded sessions is the most ideal lecture format in my opinion. The discussion sections were great for clarification and expansion of the concepts covered in class. My TF did a great job at facilitating casual conversation guided by genuine student interest while also hammering down on the concepts we needed to understand for the class. The midterm was offered in two proctored sessions: one during regular class time and an alternate session at a time voted on by students that could not make it to the first. It was clear throughout this course that the teaching staff cared about their students' success and health.
I think that the virtual office hours and discussion sections were a good adaptation during the covid pandemic.
Both the lectures and the discussion sessions functioned well.

Lectures on the internet did not succeed. Section over the internet failed miserably. Given that there was almost no interaction during the lectures it would have been better for the professor to simply post the videos and have us watch at our convenience.
The class worked well in a online setting, with recorded lectures, online discussion sections going smoothly, and seamless online exams.

Having the lecture recorded and accessible online was very helpful. If there was a part of lecture I missed or did not understand, I could easily rewatch the lecture, which strengthened my comprehension of the material.
Online lectures were very well led and discussion groups very easy and useful to participate in.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I loved this course as humanity for STEM students. Not as easy as I thought it would be though.
Solid course for HU requirement as a STEM major, though you will likely have seen a lot of the material already in that case
Yes, if you like philosophical thinking and pondering the nature of reality. Changed the way I look at science and math as actually modeling reality (in my case, with increased skepticism now)
Yes. The topics raised are really fun and interesting. But you should be familiar with mathematical proofs.

Yes, if you have a math background. I think that a lot of the concepts in this class build on knowledge from math and other sciences, which are only briefly summarized in the course. At times we even dive into some of the math so that the intuition behind philosophical claims make sense, and I found myself relying on mathematical reasoning a lot when attempting to support certain claims. While the class is in philosophy, I felt like the class is geared more towards people who enjoy math and its related concepts.
Yes, the course content is really interesting and in considering the paradoxes and arguments, you'll become a better thinker.
Absolutely. Really interesting course material without an overwhelming amount of work and well-suited for virtual learning.
I loved this course! Definitely recommend. One of my fave classes at Yale!
No.
I would recommend only if you are willing to put in a lot of extra work outside of class or if you already have some basic familiarity with set theory and other advanced math.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! It was very interesting, and the problem sets were really fun to think through! Professor Maxwell is great, and the class felt very welcoming and interesting.
Tricky. Not if you're a math major looking for a Hu. The math is obviously quite basic but the philosophy stuff is a bit of a pain sometimes.

Definitely, if they have an interest in math and philosophy. I personally love these two subjects, and have always been fascinated by the concept of infinity, so I loved this class. I can see how it would not be fun for someone that's not a fan of math, for the first part of the class focused a lot on set theory and required proofs on the homework. We also covered some geometry, calculus, and statistics. This class would also not be fun for someone that does not like thinking about philosophical issues, as this class consisted largely of paradoxes involving infinity. If neither of those are an issue, or if you are looking for something different/a challenge, then I recommend this class. There will be a lot of support from the teaching staff and no previous experience with any of the topics covered in the class is assumed, so you can feel comfortable in your decision to take this class regardless of your academic background.  If you are unsure about it, the topics covered in this class were really interesting and it would be worth at least shopping this class to see what it is about.
Yes, I believe that this course would be interesting, regardless of mathematical background. It has rigorous elements as well as more philosophical elements focussed on discussion.
I would recommend this course to someone who is familiar with mathematical/philosophical concepts, or who excels in those subjects.
Not really, no. If you're interested, read one of the many books covering this subject, save some time and money.
Any student who wishes to have a taste of philosophy to become a well-rounded person should take this class, as I now feel as though I understand philosophy better through this class.

This course provides an excellent presentation of the idea of infinity and allows students to engage in philosophical conversation rooted in mathematics. It is very engaging and intellectually stimulating. I would most certainly recommend this course to any student, regardless of major.
Absolutely - it is a good intersection of mathematics and philosophy.
